Title: The Man in the High Castle:
Author: Philip K Dick

Title: Small Giants:Companies That Choose to Be Great Instead of Big
Author: Bo Burlingham
My Review:
Basically a collection of anecdotes this book makes for a nice read but the point is made about halfway and then repeated ad nauseum.

All in all you might get some good ideas from this though if your in the process of starting a business yourself or not getting much satisfaction out of your current one.

Title: Building Social Web Applications:Establishing Community at the Heart of Your Site
Author: Gavin Bell
My Review: Both for experienced web developers or those just starting out building or designing social web apps this book offers a great summary of the many things you need to take into account. It offers both suggestions for your planning and design phase and best practices for building.

Title: Programming Collective Intelligence:Building Smart Web 2.0 Applications
Author: Toby Segaran

Title: The Lord of the Rings:Part 1: The Fellowship of the Ring; Part 2: The Two Towers; Part 3: The Return of the King
Author: J.R.R. Tolkien

Title: Extremely Loud and Incredibly Close:A Novel
Author: Jonathan Safran Foer

Title: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius:(Vintage)
Author: Dave Eggers

Title: The Man Who Mistook His Wife For A Hat:And Other Clinical Tales
Author: Oliver Sacks

Title: Sophie's World:A Novel About the History of Philosophy
Author: Jostein Gaarder

Title: A Short History of Nearly Everything:
Author: Bill Bryson

Title: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-time:
Author: Mark Haddon

Title: The Hitch Hiker's Guide to the Galaxy:
Author: Douglas Adams

Title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix:
Author: J. K. Rowling

Title: The New York Trilogy:(Contemporary American Fiction Series)
Author: Paul Auster

Title: Nexus:Small Worlds and the Groundbreaking Theory of Networks
Author: Mark Haddon, Mark Buchanan

Title: Guns, Germs and Steel:A short history of everybody for the last 13,000 years
Author: Jared Diamond

Title: High Performance MySQL:
Author: Balling Derek J., Jeremy D. Zawodny

Title: Somberman's actie:
Author: Remco Campert
Publisher: Stichting Collectieve Propaganda van het Nederlandse Boek

Title: Stupid White Men:...and Other Sorry Excuses for the State of the Nation
Author: Michael Moore

Title: Kuifje / 14 kuifje en het zwarte goud:
Author: Herge

Title: De avonturen van Kuifje / De zonnetempel:
Author: Herge

Title: Kuifje / 11 de schat van scharlaken rackham:
Author: Herge

Title: Kuifje / 8 de krab met de gulden scharen:
Author: Herge

Title: Kuifje / 10 het geheim van de eenhoorn:
Author: Herge

Title: After Dark - A Format:
Author: Haruki Murakami
My Review: Totally unlike any other novel i've ever read when it comes to style. Reminiscent of Japanese cinema when it comes to story.

Title: Halting State:
Author: Charles Stross
My Review: Charles Stross mixes up hip tech such as augmented reality, ubiquitous computing and virtual worlds to create an believable and exciting near future backdrop to this funny and fast paced crime novel.

Title: A spot of bother:
Author: Mark Haddon
My Review: sometimes slightly unnerving but mostly touching and funny. although quite unlike my own family it did somehow feel familiar.

Title: Debatable Space:
Author: Philip Palmer
My Review: Invokes a universe with an epic scale on par with star wars but does so with a sense of humor. Space pirates with existential angst.

Title: Little Brother:
Author: Cory Doctorow
My Review:
While i was slightly annoyed with the many sidetracks and explanations in the beginning this book ended up really sucking me in.

It does a great job of illustrating the thornier issues of security technology. If you ever wonder how all this tech might affect your day to day life this is a must read. Freedom vs. Security and all that jive.

Title: Good Omens:The Nice and Accurate Prophecies of Agnes Nutter, Witch
Author: Terry Pratchett, Neil Gaiman
My Review: entertaining read but not very remarkable

Title: Everyware:The Dawning Age of Ubiquitous Computing
Author: Adam Greenfield
My Review: For some reason i had a hard time finishing this one, got distracted by other books a lot. Eventually i must conclude this is a good read though and especially worthwhile if you have any interest in the concept of ubiquitous computing. It summarizes most of what has been going on in this field up until 2004 and adds some rather evocative questions every designer of everywhere should ask his- or himself.

Title: After Tamerlane:The Rise and Fall of Global Empires, 1400-2000
Author: John Darwin

Title: Dress Your Family in Corduroy and Denim:
Author: David Sedaris

Title: Building Scalable Web Sites:Building, Scaling, and Optimizing the Next Generation of Web Applications
Author: Cal Henderson

Title: The Black Swan:The Impact of the Highly Improbable
Author: Nassim Nicholas Taleb
My Review: Taleb is not the best writer ever and some of his less-likable character traits come through in his writing and might put you off a bit in the beginning. But hang in there and you'll be sure to get convinced his theories are sound and find yourself a little smarter in the end.

Title: Shakespeare:The World as a Stage
Author: Bill Bryson
My Review: Great little book. For the gossipy tales of shakespearean england and the gossipy tales of shakespearean historians. This book is very much a fun read, as most of Bryson's books tend to be.

Title: Blind Faith:
Author: Ben Elton
My Review: rambles on a bit. it's a horrific but funny sort of future vision but told with much lack of subtlety.

Title: Geisha of Gion:
Author: Mineko Iwasaki
My Review: Interesting insight into one of the more mysterious parts of Japans cultural heritage.

Title: Prey:
Author: Michael Crichton
My Review: pseudo scientific horror story about creepy crawlers of the nano variety.

Title: Anansi Boys:
Author: Neil Gaiman
My Review: Awesome tale of love, growing up and a whole lot of other stuff rolled up in a big and lovingly created fantasy story. Fantasy on a literary level though not the childish swords and dragons stuff.

Title: Neverwhere:The Author's Preferred Text
Author: Neil Gaiman
My Review: Less intelligent than some of his other books but still highly entertaining. Reads like a nice fantasy tv series somewhere along the lines of dr who.

Title: Programming Google App Engine:
Author: Dan Sanderson
My Review: Seems its rather outdated. Every time I picked this up to look up a problem at hand it was incomplete or just wrong. Reads like someone copy pasted the official docs with some minor tweaks here and there.
